Gra jest wyśmienita! Z pewnością mogę dać jej 7/10.
Portal jest bardzo dobry. Fizyka przedmiotów jest wspaniała, nic dziwnego, to silnik Source. Myślałem że będzie trudniejsza, ale nie.
 Ale są też minusy tej gry. Jednym i najwarzniejszym jet to że gra jest bardzo, i to bardzo krótka. Całą grę przeszedłem w niespełne cztery godziny! To bardzo mało. Miałem nadzieję że będę grał w nią długo, ale widać się zawiodłęm.
 Mam namyśli że Portal 2 jest dłuższy i trochę więcej się nim pobawię.
Polecam i życzę miłej gry. ~BRIDE~

Portal is part of the HL2 universe and thus shares the same story to a certain extent.

Valve know how to make single player games. This one is quirky, funny, random, different, odd...what else...rather dark too.

Buy it! Even if it's just for the Half-Life 2 references!

Portal вышел в 2007 году в составе Orange Box, как дополнение к новому Half-Life и Team Fortress 2. Valve не прогодали. Игра сделанная новичками, игра в которой двое из трех центральных персонажей не произносят не слова за игру, а третья - не появляется в кадре до самого конца, игра состоящая из белых лабораторных корридоров - совершает фуррор.
Это невероятное помешательство на логическом пазле - игра ставшая культурным феноменом. Тогда казалось - что ничего лучше придумать уже нельзя. Valve доказала обратное в 2011.

A humorous first person puzzle game pitting you against an evil overlord computer system with your only "weapon" being a Portal Gun that lets you open 2 color-coded portals on certain walls & floors. A great twist on Valve's penchant for box & physics puzzles with an engaging story that will pull you through the (relatively short) campaign. If you crave more after the campaign you can download or create your own custom maps using the same tools as any other source game. An easy to pickup and play must-play for anyone.

I mean, what else is there to say, really? I'm sure everyone who regularly uses Steam owns this one, if not played it at least once. Simply put, it's a part of this site's DNA by now. So well-weathered by now that most people today have probably forgotten it once was subjected to endless annoying memes about dishonest pastries and a song about a computer gloating that they're not dead.

So I'll just run through some things I like about the game, I'm sure you don't need a set-up to what the story is or what the gameplay's about.

- the way it integrates FPS mechanics minus shooting with puzzle-solving. It's executed fluidly, controls are tight and puzzles that make you think outside the box without being aggravating.

- the general tone of the game. The scrawlings on the wall in the red-rusted back areas are both hilarious and disturbing (too bad part of the humor of at least one of the walls is the ever over-quoted "THE CAKE IS A LIE." I really envy people who got to play this game around when it came out). GLaDoS as a kind of parody of Shodan of System Shock fame (not sure if that was the inspiration but I'd be surprised if nobody on the team ever played those games) has some funny lines of her own, especially in the second half of the game where you're in "survival mode" for lack of a better term.

- the portal gun. Well, of course, the game revolves entirely around it, no way would I recommend this game if I found it subpar! This ties in back to my comments about how well-designed the puzzles are, but just the mechanic itself... whoever came up with it is a genius. That they were able to implement something that seems so complicated to program so flawlessly also shows the remarkable talent of the team behind the game. It's so straightforward yet offers a remarkable number of possibilities for making it through levels if you're clever enough (and indeed it would seem to be a speed runner's wet dream).

- post-game challenges. If you want to test your mettle even further, the game offers two modes with different challenges for segments of certain levels. Advanced maps involve more difficult alterations of certain areas, which might include, say, having portal-proof walls in places you relied entirely on during the normal game. They definitely are hard, but I managed to finish all of them, so if you like the game and want more of it, that's the way to go. Challenge maps involve you completing segments either with as few portals possible, within an allotted time limited, and with fewest steps taken. Getting bronze medals on these are hard enough, gold medals are near-impossible if you ask me. But if you want a challenge, you got it there!

- the soundtrack. No, I'm not talking about "Still Alive" (which still is a good song even if the Internet sort of killed that one) but the ambient music that plays occasionally throughout. Some very haunting sounds that fit the environments, and lend well to its balancing act of comedy and something more serious.

Overall, a very positive verdict. Now is it one of my absolute favorite games? To that I'd have to say, no. This is the only game so far that Yahtzee has called "perfect" in that he could not think of a single flaw in the game (he recanted that with his Portal 2 review, where the "flaw" he found was the game's meme-loving fanbase). And indeed this is a game that one would be hard-pressed to find fault with. It is a game very singularly focused on what it does, cuts the fat, and with not a bug or programming error to be found, QA'd to perfection. In the end though, it is still a linear puzzle game, albeit a clever one, that's short and is what it is. My absolute favorite games are abundant in flaws, but "greatness" and "perfection" are two distinct concepts in my view. Don't take this as a knock on the game, in fact if you haven't played it already DO SO NOW. It's just that, I agree it's a game without a speck on it, but it doesn't quite move or engage me in the way that games riddled with flaws but make up for it with far more amazing content have. So, I guess you could call that a flaw in itself? Heh.

The first-person puzzler that started the series.  I found it to be more challenging than Portal 2, but it is a very short game nonetheless - you can comfortably complete it in about an hour without even trying to speedrun it.

This is the game that showed the world that a first person game doesn't need combat to be good.  Also that first person puzzle games are awesome and first person platforming *gasp* works well.

There is nothing about this game that isn't simply fantastic.  The writing and voice acting are top notch, the puzzles are all well-designed and provide great variety.  The portal mechanic is pretty unique, though some other games have copied it since then.  The puzzles can get fairly mind-bending towards the end, but nothing really frustrating, thankfully.

I suppose my only complaint is that the game is quite short, though that's what it was designed to be so it's not really a problem.

This game has been free twice, why haven't you played it yet?!?

Far too short to be considered a game, though it was fun and at least it made me think. Though I enjoyed Portal 2 far more than Portal 1, the latter was far too repetitive for my liking. I'd give it 7/10

The fantastic, black-humor rich puzzle game is something you can't miss. Whether you like FPS games or not, this seems to appeal to any gamer at any level. The game helps you learn the basics, then lets you start to knit those ideas together to progress in the later levels. That and the constant sharp wit of GLaDOS as your only companion in the facility makes for an interesting ambience unseen in most games. Don't miss this.
